Big thanks to those who helped us create this urgent road map. The @USProgressives are proud to team up with @UniteThePoor, @communitychange, @MoveOn, @SEIU & other organizers who have long been leading the fight for racial, social, economic, immigrant, and environmental justice.

People across America gave us a mandate to fight for them, to respond to the root causes of suffering, and to transform the structures of this country so people thrive‚Äînot just try and survive.

Now, we must deliver. And with The People‚Äôs Agenda, we‚Äôre ready to do exactly that.

7‚É£End corporate greed and corporate monopolies to end poverty and stop poor and working people from getting poorer while corporations and the rich get richer. This includes strengthening antitrust laws and making the wealthy, corporations, and Wall Street pay their fair share.

6‚É£Stop endless wars and finally invest in diplomacy and peace. This includes ending massively increasing Pentagon budgets that fuel wars and sap communities of vital investments in housing, education, transportation and infrastructure, health care, clean energy, and child care.

5‚É£Dismantle racism and inequality in all institutions to create justice, ensure equality and opportunity for all, and end the racial wealth gap. Additionally, we are committed to humane immigration reform while also meeting all trust obligations to Tribal Nations and communities.

4‚É£Defend and expand voting rights, strengthen democracy, and end corruption to return the vote and the voice back to the people. This includes taking on the dominance of big money in politics and reining in lobbying.

3‚É£Ensure health care for all. As we work towards Medicare for All, we must automatically enroll anyone who loses their job into Medicare, expand Medicare to lower the eligibility age to 50 and cover those up to age 25, protect reproductive care, and lower prescription prices.

2‚É£Put people back to work, give workers more power, and transform to a clean renewable energy economy. This includes investing in a bold green infrastructure package that prioritizes frontline communities while dramatically curtailing air, water, land, and climate pollution.

1‚É£Provide COVID-19 relief that actually meets the scale of this devastating crisis and addresses the disproportionate harm to BIPOC and other vulnerable communities. This includes protecting essential workers, sending grants to businesses, and putting money in people's pockets.

RT @HouseSmallBiz JUST IN: The House has voted to pass a COVID relief bill filled with provisions to get 100s of billions in aid to struggling small businesses NOW. 

Read Chairwoman @NydiaVelazquez's statement on the bill's passage.

But our efforts do not end here. We will continue to seek more assistance next year because Main Street, especially our independent restaurants, and working families deserve for us to come back to the table to provide a lifeline while we await vaccine distributions.

This agreement secures:
-Accelerated vaccine distribution
-Rent relief, food assistance, enhanced unemployment insurance & direct payments for Americans
-Strong support for small businesses

So, while I am disappointed in my Republican colleagues and recognize this bill is not ideal or as comprehensive as the Heroes Act‚Äîit will provide some much-needed relief to the American people until we can pass a more robust stimulus under the Biden Administration.
And let me be clear‚Äî$600 in direct payments and an additional $300 per week in unemployment is not enough‚Äîin fact, it‚Äôs just half of the aid that we passed in the CARES Act.

I just voted in favor of the COVID relief bill in the House because the American people cannot wait another day. It is shameful that it took this long for my colleagues on the other side of the aisle to come to the table.

As shuttered venues like cultural institutions and movie theaters, that depend on large crowds to survive faced difficulties accessing PPP, this bill creates a new $15 billion dollar grant program to target these establishments that have experienced a dramatic decline in revenue.

It'll address what we have been hearing on the ground from small businesses‚Äîthe need for cash infusions through grants. By establishing new guardrails and allocating $20 billion to the EIDL grant program, we are targeting the hardest hit small businesses to receive these grants.

Our @HouseSmallBiz team has put together a factsheet for more information on how the relief bill will help small businesses. https://smallbusiness.house.gov/uploadedfiles/12.21.20-stimulus-fact_sheet_-sbc.pdf

It would also set-aside $15 billion for small community banks, small credit unions, and small agricultural
credit institutions; and $15 billion for mission-based community lenders like CDFIs, CDCs, MDIs and microloan intermediaries.

It would also create two set-asides for small businesses borrowers with 10 or fewer employees and small
businesses in underserved areas for loans up to $250,000:
o $15 billion set-aside for initial PPP loans; and
o $25 billion set-aside for second PPP loans.
This bill would ensure PPP funding is targeted to small businesses, not large publicly funded companies by preventing publicly traded companies from receiving PPP funds.

By allowing states to enroll COFA citizens in Medicaid, we are upholding the promises we made to those in the Freely Associated States.

And we're supporting places like Hawaii that have traditionally stepped in to provide health care for the COFA community.

Our work has only become more urgent as COFA communities experience overwhelming rates of infection and death from the pandemic.

Last night, when a long-overdue deal was reached on COVID relief, Congress finally included the restoration of Medicaid access to COFA citizens.

Hawaii‚Äôs Congressional delegation has fought for decades to restore Medicaid access for COFA citizens.

I first introduced legislation to do so when I served in the House. And then again in 2013, 2015, 2017 and 2019. We got so close to passing it so many times.

But in 1996, a legislative error kicked those citizens off Medicaid.

That error led to high uninsurance rates and untreated diseases like diabetes and hypertension leaving COFA citizens vulnerable to more serious complications from #COVID19.

In exchange, citizens of those countries could live, work, and study in the United States while receiving benefits like Medicaid.

Many COFA citizens then came to the U.S. to seek health care because of complications from the fallout of nuclear testing.

Later, the US entered into Compacts of Free Association with the Marshall Islands, Palau, and Micronesia.

Under COFA, the US receives exclusive military access to their strategic territorial waters protecting our national security in the Indo-Pacific region.

From the 1940s-1950s, the US military used locations like Bikini Atoll in the Marshall Islands as testing sites for nuclear bombs‚Äîvaporizing islands, spreading mass radiation, and forcing people to flee the only homes they knew. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EpzZ8aiXYAAo17e.jpg

19/ And finally, what would it take to create a central Office of Energy Policy, coordinating all affected agencies?  Share your thoughts on both in the comments.  More thoughts to come.  /fin
18/ I'll close with a couple questions, and perhaps teasers for future nerd threads.  First, what would the central 'tent-posts' of a coherent US energy policy look like?
17/ And that's a heck of an opportunity - in the absence of coordinated strategy, the creation of one is bound to lead to huge gains in regulatory efficiency and market certainty!
16/ That's great, but while there is a lot of overlap between energy policy and climate policy, they are not the same thing.  We also need a coordinated energy policy.

15/ Curiously, there is some consensus that this is a problem for climate policy, and I'm delighted that President-elect Biden has proposed not only a "Climate Czar" but also that climate will be an animating driver of all Federal agencies
14/ (I made the latter point nearly a decade ago, and it's still painfully true: https://grist.org/article/2011-03-22-us-energy-policy/)
13/ It's also because we still have historic policies that made sense when our economy depended on resource extraction that are no longer appropriate for our more mature economy.

12/ I could go on, but you get the point.  That's not because regulators are bad people.  It's because there is no single entity responsible for coordinating US energy policy, and so the coordination doesn't get done.
11/ We celebrate market efficiencies AND insist on cross-subsidies to ensure all Americans have access to energy without price fully reflecting their geography or time of use.
10/ We mandate the use of pollution control devices that increase CO2 emissions.
9/ We seek low energy prices for US consumers AND high energy revenue to domestic energy producers.
8/ We incentivize domestic energy security AND incentivize the export of finite resources beyond our shores.
7/ We incentivize accelerated fossil fuel extraction from US land AND provide competing incentives for energy conservation.
6/ The consequence is a bunch of agencies and agendas and an energy policy that is rife with conflict.  Consider:

5/ And for those who say the answer is Congress, I would point out that we have the same lack of coherent jurisdiction.  At least a half dozen different committees have authority over some part of our energy system, but none of unilateral authority.
4/ All important functions - but no agency is responsible for coordinating and maintaining a coherent and unified US energy policy.  If there is no desk where the buck stops, the buck does not stop.

3/ The Dep't of Energy manages are nuclear stockpile and oversees R&D programs.  FERC sets rates and market structures.  Interior rules on extraction from federal land.  CFTC oversees energy futures markets.  And so on.

2/ My own view (which @ronen_schatsky correctly sussed out) is "none".  This was a trick question.  I will stipulate that the lack of consensus among the Nerds of EnergyTwitter is directionally consistent with that view.
1/ First an apology to my wife and her colleagues in the market research industry.  This was a poorly constructed poll and results should be taken with a grain of salt.

This is a partial list, and as I said at the start, is not everything we want nor everything our country needs.  Such is the nature of negotiating with someone who's preference is to do nothing but tax cuts for those who already have plenty.

- $25B in emergency rental assistance, including eviction moratoriums
- $7B for broadband, targeted to poor / rural areas to keep the internet on
- $13B in food assistance (increased SNAP eligibility, TFAP, etc)
- College students with food insecurity now eligible for SNAP

- >$300B in new PPP funding to help small businesses
- Additional targeted support for entertainment venues
- Expanded PPP eligibility for restaurants
- $ to airlines that has to be preferentially used for employees\
- $69B for vaccine development, distribution, testing

But for now, let's acknowledge what we did:
- $300/month unemployment insurance
- $600 direct payments (subject to your income)
- eligibility for both of above now covers mixed-income households (e.g., where only one has a SSN)

We pushed for much more money, way back in June in the House, but McConnell ignored it.  He has acted now on this smaller, later bill because he's nervous losing his majority.  What we got isn't nothing.  But getting what we need in a few months depends on Georgia.
So be wary of anyone who tells you that (a) injecting $900B into the economy isn't a big deal OR (b) that our work here is done and we must now shift to fiscal austerity.
